title: Siri Worm
text:
Siri Worm (born 20 April 1992) is a Dutch <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a> who plays for <a href="FA%20WSL">FA WSL</a> club <a href="Eintracht%20Frankfurt%20%28women%29">Eintracht Frankfurt</a> and the senior <a href="Netherlands%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Netherlands women's national football team</a>.
Playing career.
Club.
FC Twente.
Worm emerged from the youth academy of <a href="FC%20Twente%20%28women%29">FC Twente</a>. After several seasons as a <a href="reserve%20team">reserve</a> or <a href="utility%20player">utility player</a>, she secured a place in the team at <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29%23Full-back">left back</a> during the <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20BeNe%20League">2012–13</a> season, during which FC Twente were league champions and qualified for the <a href="UEFA%20Women%27s%20Champions%20League">UEFA Women's Champions League</a>. FC Twente qualified for the Champions League 3 more times during Worm's tenure with the club.
Everton.
Worm transferred to <a href="Everton%20L.F.C.">Everton</a> in July 2017, part of a double <a href="Transfer%20%28association%20football%29">transfer</a> with teammate <a href="Marthe%20Munsterman">Marthe Munsterman</a>.
Tottenham Hotspur.
Following <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20FA%20Women%27s%20Championship">their promotion</a> to the <a href="FA%20Women%27s%20Super%20League">Women's Super League</a>, in July 2019 Worm was announced as one of seven new <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.%20Women">Tottenham Hotspur</a> signings.
Worm was released by Tottenham at the end of the 2020/21 <a href="FA%20Women%27s%20Super%20League">FA Women's Super League</a> season.
International.
She was the <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captain</a> of the <a href="Netherlands%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Dutch Under-19 national team</a> in the <a href="2010%20UEFA%20Women%27s%20Under-19%20Championship">2010</a> and <a href="2011%20UEFA%20Women%27s%20U-19%20Championship">2011</a> <a href="UEFA%20Women%27s%20Under-19%20Championship">U-19 European Championships</a>.
In October 2012 <a href="Coach%20%28sports%29">coach</a> <a href="Roger%20Reijners">Roger Reijners</a> called Worm up to the senior national team, as a replacement for the injured <a href="Petra%20Hogewoning">Petra Hogewoning</a>. She won her first <a href="Cap%20%28sports%29">cap</a> on 25 November 2012, in a 2–0 <a href="Exhibition%20match">friendly</a> win over <a href="Wales%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Wales</a>.
Worm was named in the Netherlands squad for <a href="UEFA%20Women%27s%20Euro%202013">UEFA Women's Euro 2013</a> in <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a>. She made a <a href="Substitute%20%28association%20football%29">substitute</a> appearance in the 1–0 defeat to <a href="Norway%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Norway</a>, replacing established left back <a href="Claudia%20van%20den%20Heiligenberg">Claudia van den Heiligenberg</a> for the last 30 minutes. In April 2019, Worm was named as one of seven players on the Netherlands' standby list for the <a href="2019%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">2019 FIFA Women's World Cup</a>.
Honours.
International.
Dutch Senior Team
